title: Meet the QUACK Team
text: The QUACK box is the product of a group of students from Harvey Mudd College, working within what’s called a “Clinic” team — clinic is like a capstone experience for Harvey Mudd engineers.

title: Meet the QUACK Team
text:
First, Some Acknowledgements
HRL Laboratories sponsored our clinic experience, with the quantum researchers Andrew Oriani, Paul Jerger, and Abbie Wessels overseeing our project from start to finish. These three expert liaisons gave us valuable insight into their laboratory work, guided the direction of our work, offered earnest and thoughtful feedback, and generally helped us develop a successful product. The student team extends our most sincere gratitude to HRL’s experts for providing us with this opportunity!
Additionally, Harvey Mudd pairs the student team with an advisor from the college. Professor Joshua Brake served as our team’s advisor, supporting us with his wealth of knowledge in electrical engineering and team dynamics. His guidance and probing technical questions were essential to the successful execution of our project, and we thank him greatly for his help!
Finally, our team would like to thank the others who helped us along the way. Thank you to Sho Uemura, who’s expert guidance through the QICK firmware and Vivado software helped our team over several hurdles. Thank you also to the staff and faculty in Harvey Mudd’s engineering department, who helped keep our clinic experience afloat with equipment and administrative services.
We hope you enjoy the QUACK box, and its many quirks. It is a first-ever prototype, after all. QUACK!

title: Ordering Overview
text:
Welcome! Use the links below to navigate to the appropriate ordering instructions:

Ordering Custom Panels
Ordering Electronics (PCBs)
Ordering Standard Hardware

title: Electronics
text:
In order to construct a QUACK box, our team designed three custom PCBs:

An input board
An output board
A coupling board

All of our custom PCBs were ordered through JLCPCB, a Chinese-based PCB manufacturing and assembly house.

title: Electronics
text:
In order to construct a QUACK box, our team designed three custom PCBs:

An input board
An output board
A coupling board

All of our custom PCBs were ordered through JLCPCB, a Chinese-based PCB manufacturing and assembly house.

title: Electronics
text:
PCB Fabrication Files
Here are the links to our PCB fabrication files:

Input Board
Output Board
Coupling Board

Each link contains three files necessary for ordering the boards, including:

Gerber Files: These files contain the information needed to manufacture the board itself, holding information like the copper traces, solder mask, drill holes, and silkscreen. It is not necessary to unzip the GERBER files.
BOM (Bill of Materials): This file lists all the components required for PCB assembly, including their part numbers and quantities.
CPL (Centroid File): This file provides the coordinates of each component on the PCB, enabling JLCPCB’s automated assembly processes.

title: Electronics
text:
PCB Ordering Instructions through JLCPCB

Video Demo of Input Board Ordering
For a demonstration of how to Pre-order parts for the input board, and how to start the ordering process, see…
Part 1: Pre-ordering and Setup.
Then, see…
Part 2: Finishing Ordering


Written Instructions for General Ordering






Note



Note that for the input board, we recommend making the internal copper layers 1oz instead of 0.5 oz. Otherwise, the rest of the ordering options match the generic process outlined below. Follow the same procedure for each of the three custom PCBs needed for a full QUACK box.



Go to JLCPCB and create an account or sign in. It is essential that you are logged in any time you want to do anything meaningful with JLCPCB, like ordering or preordering.




PCB Ordering



Pre-Order Components, as shown in the Part 1 video demo above. Use this Google Spreadsheet to reference the “English” versions of the BOM, which includes Part numbers. Note that you’ll need:

5x Assembled Input Boards
5x Assembled Output Boards
2x Assembled Coupling Boards

Upload your Gerger files as indicated in the image below. 
After processing, the page will show all of the options for ordering the PCB. Most of the defaults are okay, but we recommended using the these following options:

Choose Plugged for Via Covering.



For the Input Board, leave the Economic PCB selected. For the Output and Coupling baords, select “Standard” PCB.



Choose “Confirm Part Placement,” and check Do Not Confirm Automatically.


Continue to the next step by clicking “Next”. 
Upload your BOM and CPL files then click “Proceed BOM & CPL”.



Select any unspecified parts, and confirm the displayed BOM. Make sure you have the quantities of all parts in stock. Continue to the next step by clicking “Next”.



Continue to the next step by clicking “Next”.







Note



Most likely, the parts on this page will not align properly. This is okay. Per multiple conversations with JLCPCB, their rendering software can struggle to visually align components and it is not a cause for concern. They have an engineer manually align this render after an order is placed. By selecting “Confirm Parts Placement” in step 4 above, we will get a chance to check their work before giving the final order a go.




Click “Save to the cart” and proceed to checkout!

title: QUACK
text:
Art by Zoe Worrall


Welcome to the QUACK box user website! Here, you’ll find information on creating and using your own QUACK box.
What is a QUACK box? It is a modular and scalable voltage control system that’s optimized for quantum experimentation. Software and Firmware control is built from and compatible with the open-source QICK system. The qick-quack package allows users to use the QUACK box to natively generate custom calibration PvP plots, and offers full setting and PvP control of up to 32 DAC channels.
Check out the Quack Start page above to get the fastest start on building your own QUACK box.
Check out the QUACK Team page for more a little more about what this project is, and how it came about!

title: Editing the QuACK firmware
text: This is where Zoe/Cam copy paste a large chunk of the final report lol

title: QUACK Start
text:
You will need the following items to correctly summon the QuACK. For more information on each step, see the Detailed Instructions tab in the navbar.

1 working qick setup including RFSoC, RFSoC accessories and software
2 to 32 CN0531 DAC boards
1 to 4 QuACK input boards
1 to 4 QuACK output boards
1 QuACK coupling board
1 Custom Front Panel
1 Custom Support Panel
1 5-12V power supply (minimum 5A for full 32 DAC system) (output as either Molex-6 Minifit or two Banana Connectors)
1 qickquack installation
Tools for modifying stock enclosure back panel
Flathead and Phillips screwdrivers
Ribbon Cable Crimper, or some ingenuity with pinching flat things
A fair bit of time
Some patience
Stale bread (quantity varies) (quack)



There are three main places that a user will have to go to order items for the QUACK box.

JLCPCB – Custom Printed Circuit Board (PCB) Manufacturer and Assembler

Input Boards (5)
Output Boards (5)
Coupling Board (2)

Front Panel Express – Custom Front Panel Manufacturer

Custom Front Panel (1)
Custom Support Panel (1)

Digikey

Everything Else (screws, nuts, spacers, cables, stock enclosure, etc.)


To get started on this list, head over to the Detailed Instructions -> Ordering Overview page. Work your way through the 3 pages found there.
After all of your items have come in, head over to the First half of the Detailed Instructions -> Assembly page to do some basic preparation and testing of components.
Once ready, continue on the same page to assemble the full system. That will be a wrap on hardware setup!



QuACK expands on both the firmware and software aspects of QICK.
If you are content to use what we have provided (which should definitely be your starting place if you’re just checking it out the first time), the two files you need are quack.bit and quack.hwh. If you want to edit the QuACK firmware, go you, because that’s an advanced operation. See the Advanced Usage tab.
The software upgrades provided by QuACK are all contained in the qickquack package. You can use pip install qickquack to check it out on your laptop, but you’ll need to follow the instuctions in Detailed Instructions > Installation if you want it on the RFSoC (the only place it’s actually useful fyi).

title: QUACK Start
text:
QuACK expands on both the firmware and software aspects of QICK.
If you are content to use what we have provided (which should definitely be your starting place if you’re just checking it out the first time), the two files you need are quack.bit and quack.hwh. The software upgrades provided by QuACK are all contained in the qickquack package. You can use pip install qickquack to check it out on your laptop, but you’ll need to follow the instuctions in Detailed Instructions > Installation if you want it on the RFSoC (the only place it’s actually useful fyi).

title: Advanced QuACK Usage
text: Hello, fancypants. If you’re here, it’s because you aren’t happy with what we did (hey, we’re college kids) and/or you have an awesome idea that never occured to us. We thought this might happen so we left some notes to help you get started.

title: Advanced QuACK Usage
text: Editing the QuACK firmware

title: Software Installation
text:
Before You Start…



This page assumes that you already have a working installation of qick. If you don’t, please follow qick’s quick start guide before continuing here.

title: Software Installation
text: Clone the qickquack repository

title: Software Installation
text: Move to RFSoC

title: Software Installation
text: Install qickquack locally

title: Software Installation
text: Run test notebook

title: Assembly
text: This page will walk a user through the process of assembling their own QUACK box. First, they should have acquired all materials needed to assemble the unit. See the Quack Start page for more information.

title: Assembly
text:
Ribbon Cables
There are two styles of ribbon cable that must be assembled, and they are worth calling out separately. Please be careful with this step—if not assembled correctly, the system can be shorted.

3 Daisychain Cables
Cut 3 strips of the ribbon cable into 5-7 inch pieces. Then, crimp the connectors to the end exactly as shown in the image below, paying careful attention to which side the tab is on.






Figure 1: Daisychain Cable Construction





1 FPGA-in Cable
The FPGA-In cable is constructed in a fundamentally different way. In our setup, we used a 12-24 inch strip of cable. Pay careful attention to the orientation of the connector and tab.






Figure 2: FPGA-In Cable Construction



Using a significantly longer length helps differentiate between the daisychain cables and the FPGA-In cable. It may also be helpful to physically mark them with a Sharpie in some distinctive way.

title: Assembly
text:
Enclosure Back Panel
In order to attach the support panel to the enclosure’s stock back panel, some modifications must be made in the stock panel. Specifically, M3 mounting holes must be drilled, aligning with the support panel’s corner holes. This allows the support panel to mount onto the stock back panel, but doesn’t leave any room between the two metal planes for the Coupling PCB to sit. So, using either a hole-saw, laser cutter, water jet, or (in our case) a metal hole punch, clear a Coupling PCB-sized hole into the stock panel.






Figure 3: Our modified stock back panel. Note: the current Support Panel design has been slightly shrunk in the vertical direction, so the corner mounting holes will not extend into the top and bottom flange areas. This change is not pictured above.



We found it most effective to use the actual support panel and Coupling PCB, alongside a Sharpie, to mark where the mounting holes should be drilled and the panel should be knocked out. The horizontal alignment of the support panel on the stock back panel doesn’t particularly matter, though somewhere in the middle is best.

title: Assembly
text:
Electronics Defect Testing
Our experience with JLCPCB has shown that manufacturing defects can sometimes occur. Before assembly, we recommend testing the following elements of the electronics:

Test each individual board with an ohmmeter between the red power terminals and the black ground terminals. They should exhibit resistance of greater than 10 kOhms minimum—in our testing, it was greater than 1 MOhm. Any less than this may indicate a short between the power and ground terminals, and the board should not receive power.
Follow the Input Rack assembly instructions below to connect up the ribbon cables and lead/follow selectors. Repeat the ohmmeter power test described above.
To this functionally assembled input board rack (even if not screwed together), connect up all of the power cables to the input coupling board. Testing the Molex 6-pin power connector, repeat the ohmmeter power test.
Ensure that the pins of your power supply match the expected inputs of the Molex 6-pin power connector. This pin-out should be described on the back panel board, for clarity.

These tests do not guarantee functionality, but they should at least ensure that nothing shorts, melts, or blows up due to being plugged in.

title: Assembly
text:
V-Cut Snapping
The Output and Coupling boards come as panels. In order to separate these panels, we have put “V-Cuts” along the lines where we want to separate the unused portions from the final use portions. V-Cuts are weak points which are intended to be cleanly snapped in two.
Using your hands or a pair of pliers, carefully snap the V-Cut lines of the output board until they appear as shown below (note that they are pictured in a full assembly, focus on the shape of the 4 boards):

Similarly, the coupling board comes in a panel, but with two portions intended for use. The left portion is intended to be mounted to the custom support panel on the back of the enclosure. The right portion is a helpful adapter, allowing someone to use a D-Sub 25 connector to hook straight up to the FPGA’s GPIO.

title: Assembly
text:
DAC Soldering
The CN0531 DACs come ready to use out of the box, but have some optional features that can be enabled. These features can be enabled by soldering a jumper pad on the back of the CN0531 cards. Specifically, our system requires following feature:

LDAC. Bridge/connect P14.

This feature allows for the DACs to receive a new data transmission without actually updating the DAC output yet. Thus, multiple DACs can asynchronously receive the data transmissions for their next value, but all update synchronously with a pulse of LDAC.
Researchers may, however, also make use of the following two features. They are not yet built for native support on the qick-quack package, but are described in brief detail below. See the AD5791 datasheet available here for more information on these signals.

CLR. Bridge/Connect P15. Not built into qick-quack.

CLR control is not built into the qick-quack package. However, a researcher may find that it comes in handy. The DACs have a CLR register, and pulsing the CLR line will set a DAC’s output to this CLR value. In this way, the entire system can set to a known state without having to manually send all 32 of these clear messages. Sending a custom SPI message in Mode 3 (config mode) could allow a user to experiment with this feature.

RESET. Bridge/Connect P16. Not built into qick-quack.

RESET control is not built into the qick-quack package, but can be accessed in Mode 3 (config mode). This feature may be similarly useful to researchers. Pulsing this line low resets the entire DAC setup to it’s power-on status. Note that, after use, all DACs will need to be reconfigured.

title: Assembly
text:
Enclosure
Lets focus in on the enclosure itself. Set aside the stock front panel—you won’t need it—and substitute in the custom front panel.






Figure 5: Enclosure Construction – Exploded




Step 1.1: Front and Sides
Begin with assembling the front panel to the side panels, using the stainless steel flanges and stock enclosure screws. The instruction manual that came with the enclosure may be helpful here—we follow the same process.






Figure 6: Enclosure Front Flanges









Figure 7: Enclosure Front and Side Panels





Step 1.2: Bottom






Figure 8: Enclosure Bottom Panel



Rest the bottom panel inside the frame that you have built, then attach the two screws towards the front. Do not attach the screws in the middle yet. These two screws are the same as are used in the stock enclosure assembly.






Figure 9: Enclosure Bottom – Only screw in the front screw, on each side.





Step 1.3: Back Panel
First, the Coupling PCB should be attached onto the Support panel. This requires the longer 16.00mm M3 screws, M3 nuts, and the longer 5.20mm nylon spacers (MNI-4-10).






Figure 10: Coupling PCB and Support Panel – Exploded









Figure 11: Coupling PCB and Support Panel – Assembled









Figure 12: Coupling PCB and Support Panel – Side View, with Spacers Shown



Next, attach the support board to the modified back panel using the same M3 long 16.00mm screws and nuts.






Figure 13: Support Panel to Back – Exploded. Note: The updated Front Panel design files are skinnier, and the corners of the support panel should not intrude on the flanges of the back panel.









Figure 14: Support Panel to Back – Assembled



Finally, attach the back panel to the rest of the enclosure using two of the stock enclosure small screws, and two stock larger screws with nuts. Again, see the manual that came along with the stock enclosure for more on this—we followed the same process.






Figure 15: Back Panel – Exploded









Figure 16: Back Panel – Assembled, Interior





Step 1.4: Output PCB Attachment






Figure 17: Output PCBs – Exploded



Make sure you have collected the above materials – 4 output boards, 12 long 16.00mm M3 screws and matching nuts, and 16 long 5.20mm nylon spacers (MNI-4-10). Assemble onto the front panel as shown below.






Figure 18: Output PCBs – Assembled









Figure 19: Output PCBs – Top View, Spacers Shown





Finished Enclosure
Note that after completing steps 1.1-1.4 above, the enclosure should be assembled. It is missing the top panel—leave it off while you complete the following steps. Further, make sure that you still have not assembled the two screws that go into the middle of the side panels, into the bottom panel. Here, we have replaced the stock enclosure short screws with 16.00mm long M3 screws and nuts. These will be used to help attach the input board stack-up to the enclosure securely.






Figure 20: Finished Enclosure

title: Assembly
text:
Input Board Stack-Up
Turning now to the right half of the full exploded view (Figure 4), lets assemble the input board stack. To do so, you’ll need 4 input boards with a 2-pin jumper for each. To structurally stack them up, you’ll need 6 M3 nuts, 18 M3 PCB standoffs, and 6 M3 short 6.00mm screws.
Note that we have labelled each of the boards we received with a masking tape number. This helps with tracking which boards have been tested, according to the system outlined above in Preparation – Electronics Defect Testing. It also helps to track future errors.






Figure 21: Input Boards, Structural Stacking Elements, and Jumpers



Additionally, we have created the following 3D printed support system, designed to center the input board stack within the enclosure, and to keep it from knocking around inside the box. Note that only the rectangular units on the upper left and right are required for this function, but we will show our construction with the full bottom support in place.






Figure 22: Printed Support – Exploded









Figure 23: Printed Support – Assembled



Also, have your ribbon cables on hand.

Step 2.1: Bottom layer
Assembling the bottom layer takes the most care—the upper layers are more standardized. Begin by securing 4 standoffs in the corners of one of your boards. PCB standoff through the top, nut to secure on the bottom.






Figure 24: Bottom Layer – Edge Standoffs



Place this assembly on top of your 3D printed supports. Make sure that, if you have the full bottom panel, the DAC slots are aligned with the DAC pmod ports on the input board. Attach these 4 standoffs to the corners with a second set of 4 M3 nuts. There should now be 8 nuts screwed on the 4 standoffs.






Figure 25: Bottom Layer – Back with only Edge Standoffs



Next, attach the middle two PCB standoffs and screw these in as well, using two M3 nuts.






Figure 26: Bottom Layer – Middle Standoffs Going In









Figure 27: Bottom Layer – Secure Middle Standoffs





Step 2.2: Secure To Enclosure
Place your bottom layer in the enclosure. Use the leftover screws from earlier in the enclosure process, described in the Finished Enclosure section.






Figure 28: Bottom Layer in Enclosure – Exploded









Figure 29: Bottom Layer in Enclosure – Assembled









Figure 30: Bottom Layer in Enclosure – Close-Up





Step 2.3: Designate Leader or Follower
Worth calling out as it’s own step—the entire system will not work if the user does not designate each and every board as either a “leader”, connecting to the FPGA-In connector, or a “follower”, connecting to the Daisychain-In connector.
By default, neither connection is enabled. The board will only receive a valid input from the mutually exclusive connectors once one of the two pins has been jumped using the 2-pin jumper.






Figure 31: Jumper (set to follower on the bottom layer)



If a user wanted to only use up to 8 DACs, then they would connect this pin to the FPGA-In side and connect the FPGA-In connector up to the coupling board. However, we are assuming here a system of up to 32 DACs, and so we plan to build 3 more layers on top of this bottom layer. Thus, we will designate this board as a “follower”, connecting the jumper between the GND center pin and the Daisychain side.


Step 2.4: Add Second Layer
Using 6 standoffs and another board, add to the stack!






Figure 32: Second Layer Added



Make sure to designate this board as a follower, the same as you did to the bottom layer.
In order to electrically connect the two layers, take one of your 3 Daisychain cables and attach it from the top board’s Daisychain Out to the bottom board’s Daisychain In, as shown below.






Figure 33: First Daisychain Cable, assuming that the bottom layer is the terminating board (end of daisychain).





Step 2.5: Repeat for Third Layer






Figure 34: Third Layer Added









Figure 35: Second Daisychain Cable, assuming that the bottom layer is the terminating board (end of daisychain).





Step 2.6: Add Fourth Layer
This step differs slightly. Instead of using PCB standoffs to secure the top layer, we will instead use the short 6.00mm M3 screws to tighten into the existing standoffs rising from the third layer.
Also, this layer gets the designation of leader board, connecting the jumper to the FPGA-In side.






Figure 36: Final Fourth Layer Added



Note that the jumpers should look like this, going down the line:






Figure 37: All Jumper Arrangements (bottom 3 red are Daisychain “followers”, top is FPGA-In “leader”).



Finally, add in the third and final daisychain connector.






Figure 38: All Daisychain Cables Connected.









Figure 39: Fully Assembled Input Board Stack.





Step 2.7: Add Power and FPGA-In Cable
Taking the last and special FPGA-In ribbon cable, attach it between the leader board on the stack and the coupling board.






Figure 40: FPGA-In Cable Added



Next, connect a Molex Microfit 2-pos Power Cable between every individual input board and the coupling board. The coupling board has 4 Microfit connectors for this purpose.






Figure 41: Power Cable Attached. Note: Only one is shown.

title: Assembly
text:
Adding DACs
One may attach any amount of 1-32 DACs into this system. It is recommended that you begin filling the system from the bottom, and build your way up. Each DAC must first be connected with a Adafruit 261: JST 2-Pin Cable Assembly. Connect the red leads to the middle screw terminal port, the Vout. Connect the black lead to the GND left screw terminal port. Shown below.






Figure 42: Wiring of a single DAC



Some users may prefer to instead twist the cables.






Figure 43: Twisted Output Wire



However you attach it, and whichever pmod header on the Input Board Stack you choose to plug this DAC into, just make sure that you plug the output cable into the output board SMA port which is directly across from that pmod slot. Match the 4x8 grid of pmod headers to the 4x8 grid of output board SMA ports.






Figure 44: DAC Plugged In



With that, you’re done! You can slap on the rack mounting flanges that came with the stock enclosure, and attach the top panel. Before you do so, best practice is to test and debug as many signals as you can. We wish you the best of luck with your QUACK box!

title: Non-Hardware Documentation
text: Python API

title: About
text: This website tells you all that you need to know about QuACK.

title: Standard Hardware
text: In this project, we purchase some standard hardware components to assemble the QuACK system. We will provide links to the components we used, along with brief descriptions of their purpose.

title: Standard Hardware
text: In this project, we purchase some standard hardware components to assemble the QuACK system. We will provide links to the components we used, along with brief descriptions of their purpose.

title: Standard Hardware
text:
Order Check List

(1) 19” Rack Box Enclosure
(32) CN-0531 DAC Boards
(4) Pin Jumper (2-pos, 0.100” pitch)
(27) PCB Standoffs
(19) Steel M3 Nuts
(7) Short 6.00mm M3 Screw
(12) Long 16.00mm M3 Screw
(12) 5.2mm Nylon M3 Spacer
(12) 3.3mm Nylon M3 Spacer
(32) Adafruit 261: JST PH 2-Pin Female 4” cable
(1)Microfit Power Cable
(8) Ribbon Cable Connector (2x12 Female)
(~3-4 feet) Ribbon Cable (1.27mm, 28AWG, 24cond)
(1)male to male 25pin DSUB cable

title: Standard Hardware
text:
Order Details

19’’ Rack Box Enclosure:

Purpose: This enclosure serves as the main housing for the QuACK system, providing protection and organization for the internal components.
Link: 3U Rack Box Enclosure
Datasheet: Rack Box Enclosure Datasheet 

CN-0531 DAC Boards:

Purpose: These boards are used for digital-to-analog conversion, allowing the QuACK system to output analog signals.
Link: DAC board
Datasheet: CN-0531 DAC Board Datasheet 

Pin Jumper (2-pos, 0.100” pitch):

Purpose: These jumpers are used to connect the DAC boards to the QuACK system, allowing for communication and control.
Link: Pin Jumper
Datasheet: Pin Jumper Datasheet 

PCB Standoffs:

Purpose: These standoffs are used to secure the input board into a stacked configuration within the QuACK system, providing mechanical stability and separation between components.
Link: PCB Standoffs
Datasheet: PCB Standoff Datasheet 

Steel M3 Nuts:

Purpose: These nuts are used in conjunction with the PCB standoffs to secure the input/output/coupling board and other components within the QuACK system.
Link: Steel M3 Nuts
Datasheet: Steel M3 Nuts Datasheet 

Short Screw:

Purpose: These screws are used to secure various components within the QuACK system, including the input and output boards.
Link: Short Screw
Datasheet: Short Screw Datasheet 

Long Screw:

Purpose: These screws are used to secure the input and output boards within the QuACK system, providing stability and mechanical support.
Link: Long Screw
Datasheet: Long Screw Datasheet 

5.3mm Nylon M3 Spacer:

Purpose: These spacers are used to create a gap between the input/output boards.
Link: 5.3mm Nylon M3 Spacer
Datasheet: 5.3mm Nylon M3 Spacer Datasheet 

3.3mm Nylon M3 Spacer:

Purpose: These spacers are used to create a gap between the input/output boards.
Link: 3.3mm Nylon M3 Spacer
Datasheet: 3.3mm Nylon M3 Spacer Datasheet 

JST PH 2-Pin Female 4’’ cable:

Purpose: These cables are used to connect the DAC boards to the QuACK system, allowing for communication and control.
Link: JST PH 2-Pin Female 4” cable

Datasheet: JST PH 2-Pin Female 4” cable Datasheet 

Microfit Power Cable:

Purpose: This cable is used to provide power to the QuACK system
Link: Microfit Power Cable
Datasheet: Microfit Power Cable Datasheet 

Ribbon Cable Connector

Purpose: These connectors are used to connect the ribbon cable to the QuACK system, allowing for communication and control between components.
Link: Ribbon Cable Connector (2x12 female)
Datasheet: Ribbon Cable Connector Datasheet 

Ribbon Cable (1.27mm, 28AWG, 24cond):

Purpose: This ribbon cable is used to connect the QuACK system to various components, allowing for communication and control.
Link: Ribbon Cable (1.27mm, 28AWG, 24cond)
Datasheet: Ribbon Cable Datasheet 

Male to male 25pin DSUB cable:

Purpose: This cable is used to connect the QuACK system to the FPGA through the coupling board, allowing for communication and control.
Link: Female to Female 25pin DSUB cable

title: Custom Panels
text:
In this project, we designed two custom panels:

A front panel to replace the enclosure’s stock front panel, including cutouts and labels for the SMA connector outputs.
A support panel to attach to the enclosure’s stock back panel, providing a pass-through for power and data inputs.

Both panels were ordered through Front Panel Express.
In order to order the front panel, any user will first need to download the Front Panel Designer software. Note that we used version 6.4.1.

title: Custom Panels
text:
In this project, we designed two custom panels:

A front panel to replace the enclosure’s stock front panel, including cutouts and labels for the SMA connector outputs.
A support panel to attach to the enclosure’s stock back panel, providing a pass-through for power and data inputs.

Both panels were ordered through Front Panel Express.
In order to order the front panel, any user will first need to download the Front Panel Designer software. Note that we used version 6.4.1.

title: Custom Panels
text:
Ordering Our Custom Panels

Download the design files for the front panel and support panel from the links below:

Front Panel Design File
Support Panel Design File

Open the Front Panel Express software and go to File → Import to open the downloaded design files. Do step 2-4 once through for each panel, separately.




Front Panel Instructions



Review the design files to ensure they meet your requirements. You can make any necessary adjustments using the Front Panel Express software.
Once you are satisfied with the design, go to Order → Order Panel. This will direct you to the Front Panel Express ordering site to place your order. You can choose to order the panel as is or download the design file for future use.

title: Custom Panels
section: Introduction to Editing Your Own Panels
text:
Introduction to Editing Your Own Panels

Open the Front Panel Designer software and go to File → New to create a new panel file. Then, follow the instructions in the image below to customize your panel design. 

*Notes: Material of your choice [To Do: explain different material choice]

On the top toolbar, you can choose to drill a hole, add a cutout, or insert a text label. The images below demonstrate how to add a hole and a label.

  

Use the measure tool to check the dimensions/position of the holes and cutouts. The images below show how to use the measure tool




Panel Design Instructions 5


Note: I recommend measuring at specific points such as Edges (E), Center of Hole (R), or Midpoint (M) — these indicators will appear when you hover over them. If no indicator pops up, the measurement may not be exactly at the desired point.

Once you are satisfied with the design, go to Order → Order Panel. This will direct you to the Front Panel Express ordering site to place your order. You can choose to order the panel as is or download the design file for future use.
